text: [Music]
[Applause]
you
in this video you'll see how to track
and manage product usage with AWS
Service Catalog with this custom
licensing solution provided by Amazon
you can monitor the consumption of AWS
products limit access to products by
end-users and prevent cost overruns on
Amazon Web Services
the solution you're about to see
demonstrates license enforcement for a
set of private Amazon simple storage
service or Amazon s3 buckets once you
are familiar with how this example
solution works you can edit the sample
AWS CloudFormation template for use with
products in your organization this blog
post contains details on how this
solution is implemented along with a
link to the cloud formation template to
get started let's scroll down to the
template
download the template file and extract
it to a folder on your computer
next let's navigate to the s3 management
console and create a new s3 bucket to
host this content
it's recommended that you name the
bucket with the prefix shown here
followed by a dash and then your AWS
account number
now let's upload the solution code to
this bucket
you
after the upload is finished locate the
cloud formation setup file and copy the
object URL which you'll need when
creating the stack
now we can create the stack for this
example solution
paste the URL for the setup file
next enter a name for the stack
next provide the name of the bucket we
created earlier so that the setup file
can locate the rest of the files needed
to deploy the solution you can also
specify an initial user account to grant
portfolio access to in this case let's
grant access to admin
proceeded through the rest of the
configuration without making changes
acknowledge the terms and then create
the stack
the solution is now deploying after a
minute you can refresh the page and
verify the deployment was successful
next let's switch to the outputs tab to
find the Product ID which will be needed
when we configure the product parameters
scroll down and copy the value of the s3
private bucket product that was deployed
to AWS Service Catalog as part of this
example solution
now let's navigate to AWS Service
Catalog where we're signed in as an
administrator to provision a new product
here is the license management setup
product we deployed
let's provision it and see how it works
this product can be used to create and
configure a second AWS Service Catalog
product for end-users which they can use
to create private s3 buckets as these
buckets are created the consumption of
the buckets is tracked in a database
let's give this product a name
next let's specify the parameters for
this product
first paste the Product ID for the s3
private bucket product we copied earlier
next specify the email address of this
product owner this address will receive
notifications from the service as
licenses are consumed give this product
a name
you can specify a threshold where the
service notifies you in this case let's
say we want to be notified when 50% of
the s3 bucket licences have been
consumed
you can also specify a usage percentage
upon which the product is disabled and
no longer visible an AWS Service Catalog
to end-users
in this case let's specify 90%
finally you can specify the total number
of licenses this product will be able to
create for demonstration purposes let's
configure this product to allow the
creation of up to four private s3
buckets
review the product settings and then
click Launch
once the status at the top of the page
has changed to available the product has
been deployed next let's switch to the
role of an end user who is navigating to
AWS Service Catalog to provision a new
private s3 bucket the user sees the
private bucket product and clicks it to
begin the provisioning process
first they specify a name for the
product in this case the name is license
one
they also must name the bucket
if your product template includes tag
values for use in auditing and budgeting
the user can select them here in this
case let's move on
optionally the user can choose to stream
product notifications to an Amazon
simple notification service Amazon SNS
topic again let's move on
just like that the user can launch the
private bucket
scroll down to find the link to the s3
bucket that was just created
to guarantee uniqueness a gooood string
was appended to the bucket name chosen
by the user now let's fast forward to
when three of the four licenses have
been consumed and see what happens when
the last one is used
still in the user role let's return to
AWS Service Catalog and quickly create a
fourth private s3 bucket
you
now that this bucket has been created
let's navigate back to the products list
notice that the private bucket product
is no longer visible because all the
licenses have been consumed this
prevents additional buckets from being
created until the cloud engineering team
increases the number of licenses
available or the end user terminates an
instance of the Service Catalog product
by using this method an organization can
manage product usage and avoid
unanticipated service expenditures let's
switch back to the administrator role
one last time and return to AWS Service
Catalog
let's look at the product screen
from here an admin can edit a private
bucket product that has been deployed
for instance the admin can increase or
decrease the number of available
licenses the product is allowed to
consume
switching to the admins email we can see
examples of the notifications the admin
may receive
notifications can include status reports
on the current usage of a product
they can also call that when license
usage exceeds the defined threshold or
when the product has been disassociated
with the portfolio and is no longer
available to end-users
now that you're familiar with this
example solution for managing licenses
for Service Catalog products using
private s3 buckets you can download the
solution code and edit it to define your
own AWS Service Catalog products that
require license enforcement you've just
seen how to track and manage product
usage with AWS Service Catalog
thanks for watching now it's your turn
to try
